Hi everyone, this is just so if you want to use these slides later, maybe in order to use the slides where we list our favorite resources, you have access to the keyboard shortcuts to use them! I‚Äôll add that link to the chat so you can follow along and have that link available to you later.

title: Supporting R Learners on the Job During Interesting Times
text:
Panel Today
Panel convener: Joy Payton
Additional Panelists:

Ray Balise
Silvia Canel√≥n
Meghan Harris
Ted Laderas

We‚Äôll have a few questions to get started but we want to engage with you, so please use chat liberally!

Hi everyone, my name is Joy Payton, I use she/her pronouns, and I am the convener of this panel. I‚Äôm a data science educator in biomedicine and I brought together other educators who work in different areas of the same field, to talk about a topic I think a lot of us care about, which is how to support people who are trying to learn R at work, while they‚Äôre busy doing lots of other things. And we‚Äôre trying to do this now in what I‚Äôve euphemistically called ‚ÄúInteresting Times‚Äù.
I‚Äôm going to ask the panelists to introduce themselves and what their primary educational audience is, and I‚Äôll do that in alphabetical order by last name, and then I‚Äôll start asking a couple of questions. Then I‚Äôd love to open it up to you, our participants, to engage with us, and make this a dialog.
Let‚Äôs get started with our first panelist!

title: Supporting R Learners on the Job During Interesting Times
text:
Panelist Ray Balise


Raymond R. Balise, PhD
Associate Professor of Biostatistics and Bioinformatics

Teaches classes for the Division of Biostatistics and Bioinformatics at the University of Miami

Survey of Statistical Computing
Software Tools for Reproducible Research
Data Science and Machine Learning for Health Research

Mostly graduate students studying public health, biostatistics, nursing, psychology
Specializes in asynchronous instruction using R packages like learnr and gradethis as well as synchronous online instruction using tools like Zoom and Posit.Cloud.

title: Supporting R Learners on the Job During Interesting Times
text:
Panelist Silvia Canel√≥n


Silvia Canel√≥n, PhD

Data scientist at the Penn Medicine Center for Health Justice & independent data journalist
Formal training in biomedical engineering, using biomedical and spatial data science in clinical research
Currently working on an accountability journalism project (stay tuned!)
Passionate about data literacy, communication, and accessibility
Lately, I provide informal education and mentorship to other researchers on equity considerations in data visualization üìä

title: Supporting R Learners on the Job During Interesting Times
text:
Panelist Meghan Harris


Meghan Santiago Harris, MPH
Data Scientist at the Prostate Cancer Clinical Trials Consortium

Author of The Tidy Trekker Website and Blog
Self-taught data scientist and R package developer with a formal educational background in Public Health and Epidemiology.
Currently a Public Health/Data Science mentor at The University At Buffalo School of Public Health and Health Professions for undergraduate students.
Favorite method of ‚Äúinstruction‚Äù is written articles/walkthroughs and talks of all kinds.







I always emphasize self-taught - not to diminish, but to provide context and perspective

title: Supporting R Learners on the Job During Interesting Times
text:
Panelist Ted Laderas


Ted Laderas, PhD

I‚Äôve worked with many different kinds of adult learners: clinicians, bioinformaticians, biologists, finance, social scientists, engineers, and educators
Currently Director of Training and Community for Office of the Chief Data Officer, Fred Hutch Cancer Center
Recovering academic; focus is on workforce training and psychological safety

title: Supporting R Learners on the Job During Interesting Times
text:
Panelist Joy Payton


Joy Payton, MS
(For 2 more weeks) Manager of Data Education, Arcus Initiative, Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia

Teach workshops / short courses in data science (R, Python, SQL, ML, AI, NLP, etc.) for biomedical researchers and MD Fellows at CHOP and beyond (see: DENT)
Assists in Global Health Informatics efforts (Botswana, Dominican Republic, Panam√°)
Occasional adjunct professor / teach for O‚ÄôReilly
Side interests include criminal legal system statistics (in Pennsylvania we elect our judges, but voters don‚Äôt have a lot of information about how judges do their jobs)







OK, and this is my slide, I‚Äôm Joy, and I‚Äôm in transition mode, which I‚Äôll talk about later on in the panel, but while at the Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia, which we call CHOP, some of what I‚Äôve done has been to teach lots of different kind of data science topics within CHOP and beyond CHOP, as part of an NIH-funded data science training program where we reached learners in 16 countries. I also work in global health informatics and I occasionally pick up a side gig doing adjunct work or lecturing for O‚ÄôReilly.

title: Supporting R Learners on the Job During Interesting Times
text:
Question 1

Vibe coding and using LLMs to write code is enjoying a lot of press these days. Is it still necessary to teach people to write R code, and if so, how much?


So, let‚Äôs start with this one. Panelists, I‚Äôll let you come off mute as you see fit to answer in the order you wish. Vibe coding and using LLMs to write code is enjoying a lot of press these days. Is it still necessary to teach people to write R code, and if so, how much?

title: Supporting R Learners on the Job During Interesting Times
text:
Question 2

The title of this panel mentions ‚Äúinteresting times‚Äù. What is making your work as an educator particularly interesting these days, whether that‚Äôs good or bad?


Let‚Äôs move on to another question. The title of this panel mentions ‚Äúinteresting times‚Äù. What is making your work as an educator particularly interesting these days, whether that‚Äôs good or bad? Panelists, what do you think?

title: Supporting R Learners on the Job During Interesting Times
text:
Question 3

What are some of the tools and methods you find most effective to get people to use their skills and retain their use?


Here‚Äôs a question I think a lot of people will find useful when it comes to applying R to real life work. What are some of the tools and methods you find most effective to get people to use their skills and retain their use?
